NONE. ZERO. ZILCH.
If you are going to crucify OKC for losing 3 straight games to GSW, 2 of them at Oracle (where GSW is now 48-3 in 2016), you have NO CLUE.
In the playoffs, the Warriors produced a 4-game win streak from G4 vs. HOU through G2 vs. POR. So: 22 3-game win streaks BEFORE facing OKC.
Golden State produced these win streaks in the regular season: 24 5 7 11 7 7 6 4 Using conservative measurements = that's 21 3-game streaks
However, let's stick with the conservative standard. If you use the that standard, the Warriors produced 22 3-gm win streaks before the WCF
A more liberal interpretation of a 5-game winning streak is that it contains three 3-game winning streaks: Games 1-3 = 1 2-4 = 2 3-5 = 3
One extra note about GSW: Some might use a conservative measurement and say that a 5-game winning streak contains just one 3-gm win streak.

Choking requires that Player/Team A must merely demonstrate the smallest, most basic level of competence to win, but can't. THAT IS CHOKING.
Choking must also involve blowing a lead or advantage of an appreciably significant nature. In a series, this means dominating a given game.
Choking must involve abnormally bad play BEYOND REASONABLE ALLOWANCES FOR IMPERFECTION, which is a part of sports.

Part of a referee's job -- it's never truer than at the pro level -- is PRECISELY to absorb withering criticism. Part. Of. The. Job.
No normal / properly-taught referee expects a player or coach to meekly shut up after you ding him for something. Not the world we live in.
@HereGoJayAgain As a ref, you're inviting the reaction when you T him up. Refs (I've been one) are supposed to absorb that stuff.
@Brad_Hope That doesn't make Hack-A any more of a basketball play or any less of a blot on the sport.
@HereGoJayAgain He already T'd him up; part of the sequence.
Ejecting a player for profanity *after T-ing him up*, AFTER making a dubious call. Good God.
Throwing punches, threatening fans, decking someone with a planned elbow = acts which should mean immediate ejections. Appalling, S. Foster.
Officiating 101: If you T someone up, you allow the player/coach to bark at you afterward, instead of committing a game-altering action.
A technical foul is a perfectly appropriate punishment for a player losing his cool. Two techs in one instant = only for violent displays.
